result.execSummary:
The defendant Bradley J. Fowler was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Fail/Report to County Jail (10 Days +), a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 946.425(1m)(b).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes: Outstanding financial obligations are not a condition of probation & are to be paid directly to the Shawano Co Clerk of Court office within 30 days.  Debts older than 60 days will be processed for tax intercept & civil judgments.  All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.  Payment plans available for qualifying amounts.
All financials same as noted above.

consecutive to 14CF163.
Huber granted starting April 20, 2015

posted downpayment

Defendant Bradley J. Fowler appeared by video means. Defendant requested a furlough.  Judge wants to make a record.  Defendant has several cases, in jail on Arrest and commitment orders.  Defendant wants to attend a hearing in Milwaukee for his daughter.  Judge informs the defendant he is unable to grant a furlough because he has an active warrant out of Langlade County.

Order Denying Motion to Resentence

Defendant Bradley J. Fowler in court with attorney Ronald Duane Haacke.  Defendant Bradley J. Fowler in custody.  Scott E. Niemi appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Court reviews a plea questionnaire.  Defendant enters a plea of no contest.  Court advises party of their rights, finds factual basis, accepts defendant's waiver of their rights, the plea made, and finds guilty.  Remarks by Atty. Niemi regarding sentence.  Response by Atty. Haacke.  Defendant makes a statement.  Court pronounces sentence.  Appeal rights given.
